JustJs

Heavily-used helpers for javascript environments.

Check

Usage

JustJs is available on npm for server usage and distributed over a CDN for browser usage.

Browser

To use the latest version of JustJs' core over a CDN, include the following anywhere on your HTML:

<script
					src="%{browser-example-url}%"
					integrity="%{browser-example-sri}%"
					crossorigin="anonymous"
					async>
					</script>

Then, you can replace core.min.js with any of these files and/or %{latest-version}% with any of these versions.

Server

To use the latest version of JustJs on a server, install it via npm or via yarn:

Flavors

JustJs distributes multiple files when a new version is released, therefore you should pick the one that better suits your needs...

If you don't know what to choose, "core.min.js" is always a good option...

Versioning

JustJs follows the Semantic Versioning Specification (SemVer) to version each release. However, we tag the release prepending "v" to the version.

Usually, you should avoid using release-candidates (those releases that include "-rc" on the version) and use a previous/next version instead, since those are used for testing purposes and removed after a release is no longer a candidate.

If you need more information about a certain version, please check the source code on Github.

%{available-versions-table}%

History

JustJs was initially called APR and it was born as a close-source project some years ago. —When IE8 was a thing and you had to decide whether to still targeting IE6 or go straight into IE8.

The main goal of APR was to ship it together as a suite (APR-suite) within every site I'd developed. However, I let that idea vanish away and I decided to rename the project to JustJs and released it as an open-source project on Github to let other people use it. —In fact, APR-suite is still being renamed, rewritten, and added to JustJs.

Now, after some time, I'm proud to say that JustJs is still the most used library throughout my developments and it's being more active than ever...
